Calculate Rolling Slope

Source: R/rolling_slope.R
rolling_slope.Rd

Computes rolling first derivative (slope) of y over x using least squares regression within a moving window.

Usage

rolling_slope(
  y,
  x = NULL,
  width,
  align = c("center", "left", "right"),
  na.rm = FALSE
)

Arguments

y

A numeric vector of response values.

x

A numeric vector of predictor values. If NULL, uses seq_along(y).

width

An integer scalar defining the window width (in units of x) for rolling calculations.

align

Specifies the window alignment of width as "center" (the default), "left", or "right". Where "left" is forward looking, and "right" is backward looking by the window width from the current observation.

na.rm

A logical indicating whether to exclude NA values from rolling slope calculations.

Value

A numeric vector of rolling local slopes of the same length as y.

Details

The function uses the least squares formula: slope = sum((x - x_mean) * (y - y_mean)) / sum((x - x_mean)^2).

When na.rm = TRUE, NA values are excluded from calculations. If fewer than 2 valid points remain in a window, NA will be returned for that position.

See also

zoo::rollapply()

Examples

## basic usage with default centred alignment
y <- c(1, 3, 2, 5, 8, 7, 9, 12, 11, 14)
rolling_slope(y, width = 3)
#>  [1] 2.0 0.5 1.0 3.0 1.0 0.5 2.5 1.0 1.0 3.0

## with custom x values and left alignment
x <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 10)
rolling_slope(y, x, width = 3, align = "left")
#>  [1]  4.5  9.0 27.0  9.0  4.5 22.5  9.0  9.0 27.0  0.0

## handling missing values with `na.rm = TRUE`
y_na <- c(1, 3, NA, 5, 8, 7, 9, 12, NA, 14)
rolling_slope(y_na, width = 3, na.rm = FALSE)
#>  [1] 2.0  NA  NA  NA 1.0 0.5 2.5  NA  NA  NA
rolling_slope(y_na, width = 3, na.rm = TRUE)
#>  [1] 2.0 2.0 1.0 3.0 1.0 0.5 2.5 3.0 1.0 0.0
